description: From Middle English really, realy, rialliche, equivalent to real +‎ -ly.

adverbs.description: really (comparative more really, superlative most really)

entries.meaning: (literally) In a way or manner that is real, not unreal.
examples: We are to believe that by an extraordinary Conception by Means of the holy Ghost he in an extraordinary MANNER, (unknown to us) really assumed Flesh, and was by her nourished in the Womb and in due Time born in a natural Manner, and that whilst on Earth he was really hungry, and dry, and eat and drank as really as other Men, without, any Deception of Sight in us or Delusion whatsoever.
"He really is a true friend." / "Really? What makes you so sure?"

entries.meaning: (informal, as an intensifier) Very (modifying an adjective); very much (modifying a verb).
examples: But ma, I really, really want to go to the show!

verbs.description: really (third-person singular simple present reallies, present participle reallying, simple past and past participle reallied)

examples: She wished since long to die and to be reallied with her children in heaven.
